p: In order to contribute to the chemical characterization of S. blancoana subsp. mariolensis, the essential oil contents of the air-dried aerial parts of seven samples of this taxon have been determined and compared with those obtained for samples of other sages used in the region (Table 1). The essential oil content (% v/w) of S. blancoana subsp. mariolensis was in general higher than 2% (1.8–4.5%), even for a sample collected in winter (SB7), which yielded 3.8% of oil. Only one sample (SB4) gave a lower yield (1.8%). The essential oil contents of the three samples of S. officinalis subsp. lavandulifolia were always below 2% (1.2–1.3%) and lower than those shown by S. blancoana subsp. mariolensis. Finally, their hybrid, S. x hegelmaieri, gave a content of 2.5%, which is in between of those shown by the parent taxa.
